bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Merritte W. Ireland, October 16, 1941

div1.p: Hench thanks Ireland for the photograph and the copy of General Order No. 6. He discusses Truby's manuscript and suggests possible publishers.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Merritte W. Ireland, October 16, 1941
div1.opener:
October 16, 1941
General M. W. Ireland
1870 Wyoming Avenue
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Ireland:
div1.p:
I do so appreciate the kindness of yourself and General Kean in
sending me the autographed photograph of yourselves. I am delighted to have
it. It was very thoughtful of you to send me a photostatic copy of the
General Order No. 6 for Dec. 21, 1900. I had heard considerable about that
order but had not seen a copy. Am I to keep it or shall I have a “positive”
made and return the negative to you or General Truby?

My Hygeia reprints have not yet arrived but should be here in a
week or so and I will send you gladly as many copies as you may wish. I had
such a nice letter from Mrs. Lazear this last week.

I enclose a copy of a letter I am sending General Truby regarding
his revised manuscript. I think it is grand and it must be published. I've
had a rather mean time the past two weeks with a severe cold which turned into
first a sinusitis and then lingual tonsillitis--a very childish but mean thing.
This has held up my writing to General Truby but despite my illness I read the
manuscript at one sitting--from 10 P.M. till 3 A.M. one night last week.

I am taking the liberty of suggesting that, unless final arrange-
ments have been made to publish it from the S. G. O., he submit it to some
publishers. It would be more widely advertised and more attractively gotten
up if it were accepted and I think there is a really good chance.
Thank you so much for your repeated kindnesses.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
Encl. copies of letter to Gen. Truby
and letter from Dr. Hewitt
